user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtSprintf:
```c
char *UtSprintf(const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list                     Args;
    static UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf[UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS];
    static uint32               TextIndex = 0;

    ++TextIndex;
    if (TextIndex >= UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS)
        TextIndex = 0;

    va_start(Args, Spec);
    vsnprintf(Buf[TextIndex].Text, sizeof(Buf[TextIndex].Text), Spec, Args);
    va_end(Args);

    return Buf[TextIndex].Text;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtSprintf:
typedef struct
{
    char Text[UT_SNPRINTF_BUF_SIZE];
} UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t
...
#define UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS 10
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code fragments do not need investigation for Rule 8.13 because they do not involve pointers that could/should be const-qualified: Spec is already declared as const char * (compliant); va_list Args is not a pointer-to-object type requiring const qualification; the static buffer declaration (static UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf[UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS];) defines an array of structs whose Text member must be mutable because vsnprintf writes into it, so it cannot be const; TextIndex is an integer not a pointer; the typedef for UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t and the macro UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS are not pointer declarations. The only pointer-related occurrences to assess for Rule 8.13 are the function return type (char *) and the actual return expression returning the buffer pointer, which are reported above.
